awd_titl_txt: Programming as a Context for Making Problem Solving Visible: An Equity Focused K-5 Research Practice Partnership
awd_abstract_narration:
STEM domains have long provided productive contexts for problem solving research, a central learning objective in education for the 21st century. Problem solving and related constructs, such as critical thinking and computational thinking, are increasingly holding organizing power in the design and implementation of K-12 curriculum across educational domains. The Computer Science for All: Researcher-Practitioner Partnership (RPP) program is supporting this project, with an RPP team comprised of teachers, principals, researchers, professional development leaders, curriculum developers, and software engineers stretched across several institutions in Los Angeles, including three elementary public and charter schools, the University of California, Los Angeles, and a non-profit community learning center that develops CS curriculum and software. This project focuses on how to effectively teach problem solving practices in 3rd - 4th grade computer science classes, namely on how to build students' capacities to articulate their problem-solving process, understand how different strategies advance problem solving, and develop and enact new strategies for problem solving. The RPP will seed this problem solving process with 3rd and 4th graders traditionally marginalized in urban environments by designing CS lessons that promote sustained, rigorous, and collaborative reflection on problem-solving processes. This work will generate lesson templates and research findings valuable to educators interested in the intersection of problem solving and computer programming, and set the stage for larger scale research-practice partnership initiatives.

The RPP's approach will address a critical research need to understand how young students think about and pursue problem solving with code in the context of whole- and small-group classroom discourse, focused around facets of problem solving synthesized from the wider research literature: problem exploration, goal setting, implementation, monitoring, and reflection. The project team of curriculum designers, researchers, and practitioners will be informed by multiple data sources: observations of classroom practice, teacher interviews, designer interviews, school leader interviews, and bi-monthly student surveys. They will use a blend of design methodologies, agile development and design-research conjecture mapping, to iteratively and pragmatically aim to foster rich classroom discourse on CS problem solving processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Programming as a Context for Making Problem Solving Visible: An Equity Focused K-5 Research Practice Partnership - Project Outcome Report

 

Background

This project aimed to investigate, and design for, efforts that effectively teach problem solving practices in 3rd - 4th grade computer science classes. Specifically, the project sought to build students’ capacities to articulate their problem solving process, understand how different strategies advance problem solving, and develop and enact new strategies for problem solving. To do so, we aimed to build strong collaborative design practices across educational stakeholders that included teachers, principals, researchers, professional development leaders, curriculum developers, and software engineers stretched across several institutions in Los Angeles, including three elementary public district and charter schools, the University of California, Los Angeles, and a non-profit community learning center that develops CS curriculum and software. 

Outcomes

Curriculum Design

The collaborative processes we developed over the course of the partnership allowed for the design of problem solving focused lessons that embodied diverse perspectives on equity in CS education, assets and desired learning outcomes of participating teachers, pedagogy, and the organizational contexts of the schools in which the lessons would be implemented. We completed the design of five curricular units (about 4-5 lessons each) framed around the following goals: 

  • CS Education and General Education Standards

    • Common Core State Standards and Next Generation Science Standards: When possible, curriculum was aligned to ELA, Math, and/or Science state standards to draw clear connections between computer science and the liberal arts. 

    • Computer Science Teacher Association Standards: These standards are slowly being adopted across the nation. Though the Los Angeles Unified School District has not formally adopted CSTA standards at the elementary level, these standards were used as a guide for rigor and relevance for student learning. 

    • CS Domain Practices: Along with the computer programming concepts of developing sequences, loops, and functions, teachers focused on developing thinking and problem solving skills like debugging, prototyping, iteration, and reflection. 

  • Equity Goals

    • Economic Participation: Participating in emerging labor markets agentively. 

    • Development of Critical Tools: Students gaining CS-related and other ancillary knowledge and skills that will help them engage in social transformation. 

    • Development of Educational Tools: To use CS as a space to express diverse student competencies, and to develop knowledge and skills that can be transferable to other educational domains. 

  • Student Learning Outcomes

    • General Cognitive and Academic Development: Students develop general, transferable skills, mindsets, and knowledge that support broad problem-solving and academic participation.

    • Coding Knowledge and Skills Development: Students develop proficiency, mindset, and skills to successfully solve CS-specific challenges.  

    • Mindsets Towards CS: Students feel motivation, engagement, interest, sense of competency, and belonging in CS.

    • Agentic User of CS: Skills and knowledge to use CS to shape and design society with CS. 

  • Pedagogy

    • Connection to Real Life: Drawing on connections to phenomena outside of school, including the real life work of programmers, societal impacts, application in various professions and student interests. 

    • Connection to Other Content Areas: CS work informs, and is informed by student learning in other content areas. 

    • Cognitive Support for PS: Focus and Scaffolding on problem-solving processes; making cognition visible; collaboration with others; classroom problem-solving discourse; metacognitive understanding of PS process. 

    • Open-Ended, Design-Driven: Students engage in problems that are open-ended and design-driven. Asking them to construct knowledge and tools. 

    • Assigned Problem-Driven: Students work to solve a problem with an existing answer using CS concepts.

    • Classroom Culture: The curriculum helps build a classroom culture that supports collaboration, perseverance, and agency. 

    • Aesthetics and Ease of Use: Teachers and students need to find the curriculum aesthetically appealing and easy to use/learn from. 

  • Organizational Assets and Needs

    • Teacher capacity development in CS education

    • Building organizational infrastructure and pipelines for CS education



Development of Collaborative Design Practices

The project developed effective processes to engage in collaborative design cycles between university researchers, curriculum designers, and teachers and administrators from four schools. These design cycles have been developed in order to:

  1. maximally leverage the assets of each stakeholder groups;

  2. ensure the designed curriculum meet the respective needs and priorities of each stakeholder group;

  3. exchange knowledge across the stakeholder groups;

  4. continuously refine curriculum, design frameworks and processes.

  5. ensure the usability of the curriculum in individual teacher classrooms;

  6. center stakeholders’ perspectives on equitable CS education in design of CS lessons. 

 

Academic Research 

The following articles have been prepared for forthcoming publication: 

  • Gomez, K., Lee, U. S. A., & Berkhoudt, A. (Forthcoming). The Role of Teacher Knowledge and Ethos in Shaping Learning, Design Processes, and Collective Knowledge: Teacher Participation and Learning in the Co-Design of Elementary Computer Science Curriculum. In A. C. Superfine, S. R. Goldman, & M. L. M. Ko (Eds.), Changing content and contexts of teacher learning Supporting shifts in instructional practices. Advances in the Learning Sciences. 

Lee, U. S. A., DeLiema, D., & Gomez, K. (Forthcoming). Equity Conjectures in a Computer-Science Problem-Solving Focused Collaboration. Cognition and Instruction.
